intro: Brassica oleracea var. phaeusa, commonly known as Chinese kale, is a leafy green vegetable characterized by its dark green, curly leaves and thick, fibrous stalks. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other cruciferous vegetables like broccoli and cauliflower. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and produces small, yellow flowers that develop into round, pale siliques containing seeds. It thrives in cool climates and is cultivated for its edible leaves, which are rich in vitamins A, C, and K. This variety is well-suited for both spring and fall planting in temperate regions.
